results.title: Anybody's son will do
results.creator_credit: Paul Cowan, John Kramer, Bill Brind and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “War”.
Offers unusually frank insights into techniques that all armies use to motivate recruits. The film takes us to Parris Island Marine Recruit Training Depot in South Carolina, USA, to observe the rituals that will transform a motley group of eighteen year-olds into soldiers of the United States Marine Corps, unquestionably the roughest, toughest branch in the US military. It is a gripping study of what it takes to change ordinary civilians into the staple of wars, soldiers ready to kill, even to die for their country.

results.title: Notes on nuclear war
results.creator_credit: Tina Viljoen, Michael Bryans and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “War”.
This film follows the development of the nuclear arms race from Hiroshima to the nuclear stalemate of today. It examines the Western military-industrial complex and its Warsaw Pact counterpart, and explains how the concept of “limited” nuclear war came to be. Notes on Nuclear War shows the devastating effect of nuclear bombs; American and Soviet physicians describe the medical consequences and the inability of their profession to cope with the casualties. Part six of the seven-part series War, hosted by Gwynne Dyer, examining the nature, evolution and consequences of modern warfare.

results.title: Walking with dinosaurs
results.brief_description: Imagine if you could witness a Cretaceous sunset, watch as insectivorous pterosaurs chase moths in the evening, and bull triceratops lock horns over a young female. This is no longer a dream. “Walking with dinosaurs” is a six episode series that transports the viewer back to prehistoric times when dinosaurs ruled the earth. Using CGI animation, all the major eras- Triassic, Jurassic and Cretaceous, are faithfully recreated with stunning authenticity as classic natural history techniques meld with state of the art computer graphics. Filmed against spectacular natural backdrops in Chile, Tasmania and New Zealand and narrated by Kenneth Branagh, this series sets new standards for TV production and striked a perfect balance betweeen information and entertainment. In addition to the six, 30 minute episodes is a behind the scenes look at the technological and labour intesive work that went into place to make the series possible. Individual episodes include; “New blood”, “A Time of titans”, “Cruel sea”, “Giant of the skies”, “Spirits of the ice forest” and “Death of a dynasty”. Also available on DVD [318965].

results.title: The Long pain
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “W5”.
W5 is a Canadian television public affairs program. This episode deals with arthritis management and pain associated with the disease including younger sufferers.

results.title: All in the family
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “W5”.
Documentary highlighting the value of family therapy. Shows scenes in a controlled therapy session where a girl’s problems are discussed with her family. Discusses certain illnesses such as anorexia nervosa and the approach for dealing with this disease showing the progression of the therapy sessions. No other credits available.

results.title: The Risky start
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “W5”.

results.title: Four minutes to live
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “W5”.
Presented by Jim Reed, this episode of a weekly television public affairs series focusses on emergency-response healthcare. Subjects include: the need for paramedics in Ontario; Vancouver, Calgary, and Medicine Hat as the only places in Canada with advanced pre-paramedical training and personnel; and patients who have been saved by CPR.

results.title: Dying to be thin
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “W5”.
An examination of the slimmer’s desease, anorexia nervosa. Through interviews with those who have, or have had the disorder, examines the psychological and societal pressures which induce young women to diet to the point of starvation.
